title-group.subtitle: Surgical Resection of a Biventricular Diverticulum

abstract.p: Pentalogy of Cantrell is a rare diagnosis consisting of several midline defects of the sternum, abdominal wall, diaphragm, pericardium, and heart. One of the known features is ventricular diverticulum that can represent a technical challenge surgically. This is a follow-up case report of the successful simultaneous resection of a biventricular diverticulum and omphalocele repair after previous report of repair of complex intracardiac disease in the same patient.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: First described in 1958, pentalogy of Cantrell is a rare association of supraumbilical defect, diaphragmatic defect, deficiency in the xiphoid area of the sternum resulting in sternal cleft, defect in the apical pericardium, and an intracardiac defect.1 The intracardiac defects may include pulmonary stenosis, atrial septal defect (ASD), tetralogy of Fallot, left ventricular diverticulum, or most commonly ventricular septal defect (VSD).1 The surgical correction of these patients is often complex and frequently requires a staged approach. While the presence of a ventricular diverticulum may not always manifest itself symptomatically, it has been associated with complications including embolism, arrhythmia, endocarditis, and rupture.2

Although repair of isolated ventricular diverticulum has been described, surgical repair of biventricular diverticulum is uncommon.3 Balderrabano et al reported the largest case series to date, a 40-year experience with pentalogy of Cantrell, with only one case known to have had biventricular diverticula.4 In this case report, we describe the treatment of a 17-month-old patient with pentalogy of Cantrell, biventricular diverticula, and omphalocele. The intracardiac repair of double outlet right ventricle (DORV) and pulmonary stenosis 11 months prior has been reported previously.5 The patient presented at our institution with homograft stenosis, left pulmonary artery stenosis, and large biventricular diverticula contained within the omphalocele. To our knowledge, there is very limited literature reporting diverticular resection required for repair of the abdominal wall defect. Our experience is reported herein.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 17-month-old female born at 37 weeks of gestation with a prenatal diagnosis of pentalogy of Cantrell, with a large omphalocele, diaphragmatic hernia, mild sternal cleft, and complex cardiac disease consisting of DORV {S,D,D}, moderate subpulmonary stenosis, bilateral superior vena cava (SVC) with a bridging vein, and two atrial septal defects presented to our institution for surgical repair of a right ventricle to pulmonary artery (RV-PA) homograft and resection of her biventricular diverticulum.

The patient was originally treated at another institution, and her course was previously reported.5 Briefly, she spent her initial 3 weeks in the neonatal intensive care unit where her circulation was well balanced. She remained hemodynamically stable at home until approximately 6 months of age when her oxygen saturation dropped to 80%. At that time, a cardiac catheterization revealed stenosis of the left pulmonary artery and a small persistent left superior caval vein accompanied by a normal-sized bridging vein. She then underwent a repair of her DORV consisting of VSD closure to the right-sided aorta, placement of 9 mm RV-PA homograft, left pulmonary arterioplasty, closure of two 5 mm atrial septal defects, and ligation of the left SVC. No intervention on the diverticulum was performed at that time. This procedure was complicated by left-sided cerebral ischemic injury and a postoperative chylous effusion.

She had near complete recovery from the neurological injury and was clinically thriving at home. Eight months later on routine follow-up at our institution, an echocardiogram revealed severe right ventricular hypertension with a right ventricular systolic pressure estimated to be 81 mm Hg plus the right atrial “v” wave and severe conduit stenosis. The cardiac catheterization performed demonstrated homograft stenosis with a peak gradient of 83 mm Hg, moderate tricuspid regurgitation, and mildly depressed right ventricular systolic function. Angiography demonstrated the extent of the right and left ventricular components of the diverticulum including the degree of protrusion into the omphalocele (Figure 1 ).

caption.p: A, Left ventricular (LV) angiogram demonstrating anatomy of LV diverticulum into omphalocele. Very narrow lumen proximally with dilatation distally (lateral view with LAO angulation). B, Angiogram in right ventricular diverticulum, which also demonstrates very narrowed diverticular lumen with distal dilatation.
Cardiac computed tomography scan demonstrating biventricular diverticula extending into the omphalocele anteriorly in the sagittal (A) and coronal (B) planes.
A, Biventricular diverticulum dissected out of omphalocele. B, Arrow indicating tunnel into abdominal cavity/omphalocele through which the diverticulum extended.

sec.p: The patient was discharged 1 week after repair and at last follow-up visit (three months postoperative) continues to do quite well. Echocardiogram demonstrated normal right and left ventricular systolic function and no mitral regurgitation. It also showed no stenosis of the conduit, with no conduit valve insufficiency.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Pentalogy of Cantrell is a rare constellation of defects occurring in approximately 5 to 15 in 1 million live births.6,7 Although the etiology has not been specifically identified, it is thought to result from defective formation, differentiation, and migration of mesoderm during the third week of embryonic life.1 Ventricular diverticulum, which is estimated to be present in 20% to 30% of cases are thought to be a result of traction exerted on the pericardial mesoderm by the caudal migration of the transverse septum, which in turn can prevent normal levorotation of the heart and pull the primitive left ventricular cells into a diverticular appendage.7–9 Apical diverticula account for approximately 70% of this type of malformation, with nonapical diverticula arising from the subaortic area or the ventricular free wall, and biventricular diverticular being very rare.10 In one previous report, apical diverticula were always associated with midline thoracoabdominal defects and other heart malformations.11

Controversy exists with both the need for surgical resection and the timing thereof. Proponents of early resection cite reports of thrombogenic events, arrhythmias, and spontaneous rupture.12 Others suggest total resection of the diverticulum is not necessary if there is normal contractility or if the diverticular segment contains part of the coronary circulation.2

In this patient, despite normal contractility of the diverticulum and normal coronary arteries, resection was pursued in order to facilitate complete surgical repair of the diaphragmatic defect and omphalocele. Being that the initial surgical repair occurred at another institution, it is unclear why resection was not pursued at the time of the first operation but owing to the small cavitary size of these diverticula, which almost completely obliterate during contraction, we correctly predicted resection would result in little or no functional compromise.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Pentalogy of Cantrell is a complex and technically challenging syndrome with multiple factors to consider before pursuing repair. A staged approach is usually warranted. In the case of a large ventricular diverticulum that compromises repair of midline defects, resection can be undertaken with preserved cardiac function.
